summary: This is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) personnel discussing the Epstein estate's plans to liquidate properties in New York and Florida to meet tax obligations. The correspondence reveals the estate's communication with the IRS and intent to list the New York property, potentially to museums, while keeping prosecutors informed to avoid media surprise.

persons.name: Geoff
persons.context: Mentioned as the senior official ('the brass') to be updated on the Epstein estate liquidation plans, and whose instructions are sought regarding communication with the estate.

events.title: Initial email about estate liquidation plans
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office sent an initial email to the Epstein estate regarding plans to liquidate properties.

events.title: Trustees' counsel follow-up on property sales
events.description: The trustees' counsel for the Epstein estate contacted the U.S. Attorney's Office to inform them of formal steps being taken to sell the New York and Florida properties, including retaining a broker.

locations: New York property (Epstein's New York house)
keyFacts: The Epstein estate plans to move forward with selling Jeffrey Epstein's New York and Florida properties to address upcoming tax deadlines.
The estate attempted to delay IRS tax enforcement until contingent liabilities were settled, but the IRS insists on payment first with potential recoupment later.
There is noted potential interest from museums in purchasing Epstein's New York property.
The estate's trustees' counsel is proactively informing prosecutors of these steps to prevent media surprise, indicating ongoing coordination.
The correspondence highlights the estate's 'massive' contingent liabilities that are pending settlement.
